title.narrative: Responsive and Effective Collaboration to address Violence, Complex Emergencies, and Radicalization (RECOVER)

description.narrative:
Tabang Ako Siyap ko Bangsa Iranun saya ko Kalilintad ago Kapamagayon Inc (TASBIKKA); Maranao People Development Center Inc (MARADECA); Early Response Network – Lanao del Sur (ERN-LDS); and Lupah Sug Bangsamoro Women Association (LSBWA).
Additional partners include academic institutions Dansalan College, Notre Dame University and Western Mindanao State University; select local government units in the Bangsamoro, its adjacent provinces and in urban enclaves in Metro Manila; multi-stakeholder groups such as the Marawi Reconstruction Conflict Watch and Land Policy Action Group; and local community groups including women and youth networks.

The direct and indirect beneficiaries are Islamized and non-Islamized groups, local communities directly affected by transition-induced violence and new forms of violence particularly conflicts over land and resources, violent extremism, shadow economies and complex emergencies. The action wil be directed to vulnerable communities in the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region of Muslim Mindanao (BARMM), Muslim enclaves in National Capital Region (NCR) and Northern Luzon.
The targeted beneficiaries and implementing partners will include but not limited to: Peoples Organizations including youth, women networks; Local government units including Local Chief Executives, Disaster Risk Reduction Officers Managers, Planning and Development Officers, Peace and Order Councils and Muslim Consultative Councils; Policy makers including Senators, Congressperson; Academe including universities, public schools and madrasahs; Religious leaders including Ulamas and Ustadzes, Media including print, radio and social media channels and Security Sector including the police and military.

The project's specific objectives are:
(1) Consolidate and expand the use of timely and reliable conflict data and analysis that enables key actors, policymakers and stakeholders to develop relevant policy responses, strategies, advocacies and actions within and beyond the Bangsamoro. (2) Strengthen mechanisms that contribute to community resilience against the enduring threats of violent extremism, resource-based conflicts, and humanitarian crisis. (3) Support the enactment of inclusive and conflict-sensitive policies and practices that can prevent land and other resource disputes, strengthen property rights, and facilitate economic growth. (4) Influence and shape regional (BARRM) and national legislation (EOs, AOs, RAs) and policies that deters discrimination, settles longstanding issues on land use and the rights of women, youth and indigenous peoples, enables quick and comprehensive rehabilitation of conflict areas, prevents the spread of extremist violence and ensures institutional coherence from the local to the national level. (5) Foster meaningful participation of women, indigenous peoples, and the youth in concrete initiatives that aim to reduce physical, social, economic and political vulnerabilities.
